title: You can already tell Ivern is going to be LCS Pick/Ban status

No, you click once to start the grove and then it takes time for it to mature.  You can stay there or you can leave, and you can have multiple going at once.  It specifically states you can start the grove at each camp, gank a lane, taleport back to the starting camp and circle through freeing (clearing) them.

Everything I'm seeing of it shows that you only need to be there to start it and then back to clear.

The problem is though that this leaves his camps open to be stolen because if he doesn't circle back fast enough the enemy jungler can just swoop in and kill it.  It's great for clears but could leave him wide open for invades.

Ah, okay.
So he can essentially have multiple jungle camps self-farming?
But unless he's there channeling directly, it takes longer?

Here's how it works:

He goes to a camp and right clicks any of them as though to auto attack.
This starts a channel for a couple seconds, and can be interrupted by enemy damage.
After that initial channel, a "grove" is made that has to grow over the next 40-6 seconds (based on level).
When it has finished growing, he can right click the camp again to "free" them, granting him the exp and gold as though he killed them.

He can also use smite after starting the grove to instantly finish and free the camp.

Any other questions?

it's important to note that creating a 'grove' costs a lot health and mana early on, he can't even 'grove' his entire jungle without smiteing red, and even then he is really vulnerable to counterjungleing as he drops really low.
He also needs to smite blue when he reaches that if he wants to continue.

Nothing wrong with utility champions being good in organized play. If they aren't they are literally trash tier.

The meta being defined by utility as a priority over damage is why there is virtually no champion diversity in pro play.
The only proven way to acheive massive diversity in champ select would be to accept counter-picks as a viable balance measure. Just look at Dota 2.

> [{quoted}](name=Spaceman5pff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=bGrR3brv,comment-id=00060000,timestamp=2016-09-21T15:11:47.646+0000)

So you would be OK with a champion having a 60%win rate over extended periods of time?  And a dozen or so champions having above 55% win rate? Since that's what I'm seeing from dota hero balancing.

Yes, because I know that there is almost always a definite and effective counterpick available.
Also, 5-10% winrate is a small price to pay to see VASTLY more characters played more of the time.

Outside of the few forever-populars, the makeup of low-mid elo games is determined by what high-elo players and pros are playing on stream / stage. If they see virtually every champion played on stream / stage, then there will probably be even more diversity in low elo.

Lastly, A counter-balancing system allows people with good game knowledge and an understanding of how to play their matchup put up a better fight against players who just brute force their way a few tiers up the ladder with mechanics.

He's a jungler who isn't designed around shitting on everyone early game. That pretty much gets rid of any chance of him being played professionally. Junglers who lack strong early game dueling and ganking haven't been part of the jungle for seasons.
Except his intended position is support, not junlge.
It's both. He is a support champion that is played in the jungle.
If he goes support, he won't have a passive
Support is a role, not a position though. ADCs don't have to go bot lane; Jhin goes mid sometimes. His role is ADC, his position is mid lane. Iverns role is support. His position is jungler.

I see him going support, not jungle. 

1. Set up a grove at red buff on blue side or blue buff on red side, go out to ward, then come back to instaclear it. As a benefit you get double blues or double reds. 

2. You shield your engage/carries with your E for, help your engage with your Q, and have a nice secondary engage/disengage with your ult.

3. On top of that, you create bushes that could have some interesting dynamics - Caitlyn getting more headshots, using that second of vision denial for Twitch stealth, etc. I can also see some good lane pressure from bushes - side brush control just isnt enough anymore. If you clear out a sidebush and set up your bush in the lane, thats a lot of vision denial for a gank. You take for granted that you can actually see whats going on in a lane - what happens if a Lee Sin sneaks into a side brush, walks into a connecting brush in the middle of the lane? 

4. But the most important reason he will be pick or ban? He has such a unique playstyle that isnt similar to any other champion, and for that reason some players will adapt quickly (like what we saw with Huhi and Aurelion Sol and Aphro on Bard) while others will not. LCS teams have two options - practice against Ivern (which may or may not be optimal, since we dont know Ivern's optimal strats) or just ban him outright. Instead of spending hours preparing to counter one champion who may or may not be played or played in the way you think, its safer just ban it and prep other stats that work for the other 125+ champions in the game.

Sweep a side bush, block vision with a created bush, let the other mid pick between farming while risking a no gap closer needed gank and waiting it out under tower. keep smiting camps for extra farm and vision control. Shouldn't roam terribly well, but good pressure mid is good pressure mid. Waveclear not good, but should always be ahead in xp and farm.

Jungler start -> boots and 4 hp pots.

Chug pots and mark all your camps (4 pots = 600HP recovered) and I mean ALL of them.
Then smite red for HP and the buff and go gank a lane or two.

Go click on all of your camps.

Gank again.

Buy a Hunters pot, pink ward, and whatever the hell else you want.

Mark all of your camps again.

Theoretically, Ivern can be an effective jungler without ever buying a jungle item.
